query: What spatial constraint corresponds to the region where the largest city name and the uprising-related terms in the cloud were actively discussed?
answer: The bounding box coordinates (32.8, 35.9) to (37.3, 42.3) define the geographic filter that captures tweets mentioning Damascus, Aleppo, Homs, and revolution-related terms. This spatial constraint was designed to collect data from Syria during the period when these cities and uprising events dominated the discourse, as evidenced by their prominence in the tag cloud.

visual_anchors.anchor: the prominent terms 'damascus', 'aleppo', 'homs', and 'revolution' distributed across the word cloud
the Geoboxes column displaying the Southwest and Northeast coordinate pairs with the accompanying map outline

text_evidence: From December 14th, 2011 - January 10th, 2012 we collected tweets from the Twitter Firehose matching any of the keywords, geographical bounding boxes, and users in Table 1.

query: What geographic filtering strategy produced the sustained forty-thousand baseline visible in the dotted curve before its mid-December collapse?
answer: The Streaming API baseline around 40,000 tweets per day was produced by the geographic bounding box with coordinates (32.8, 35.9) for the Southwest corner and (37.3, 42.3) for the Northeast corner, covering the Syrian region. This geographic filter, combined with the listed keywords and user account, maintained consistent collection until the dotted line dropped sharply around December 21-22.

visual_anchors.anchor: dotted line (Streaming) maintaining approximately 40,000 tweets from 12-15 through 12-20, then dropping to around 10,000
Geoboxes column showing coordinate pairs (32.8, 35.9), (37.3, 42.3) with accompanying map

text_evidence: From December 14th, 2011 - January 10th, 2012 we collected tweets from the Twitter Firehose matching any of the keywords, geographical bounding boxes, and users in Table 1.

query: Which collection parameter set explains why the solid curve reaches ninety thousand during the late-December spike while the dotted curve remains below twenty thousand?
answer: The Firehose (solid red line) reached approximately 90,000 tweets during the late-December spike because it collected using the full parameter set in Table 1: all listed keywords (#syria, #assad, #aleppovolcano, #alawite, #homs, #hama, #tartous, #idlib, #damascus, #daraa, #aleppo, #سوريا, #houla), the geographic bounding box (32.8, 35.9) to (37.3, 42.3), and the user @SyrianRevo. The Streaming API used exactly the same parameters but was limited by API rate restrictions, keeping it below 20,000 tweets during the same period.

visual_anchors.anchor: solid red line (Firehose) peaking at approximately 90,000 around 12-27, while dotted line (Streaming) stays near 15,000
Keywords column listing hashtags including #syria, #assad, #aleppovolcano and Arabic text; Users column showing @SyrianRevo

text_evidence: During the same time period, we collected tweets from the Streaming API using TweetTracker (Kumar et al. 2011) with exactly the same parameters

query: Which specific user account and which Arabic-language hashtag were included in the collection parameters that yielded streaming data with coverage ranging from roughly one-fifth to nine-tenths?
answer: The user account @SyrianRevo and the Arabic-language hashtag #سوريا were included in the collection parameters shown in the leftmost and rightmost columns. These parameters, combined with other keywords and the geographic bounding box, produced Streaming data with coverage distribution ranging from approximately 0.15 (lower whisker) to 0.90 (upper whisker) as displayed in the box plot.

visual_anchors.anchor: Users column showing @SyrianRevo and Keywords column showing #سوريا among other hashtags
whiskers extending from approximately 0.15 at the bottom to 0.90 at the top of the box plot

text_evidence: From December 14th, 2011 - January 10th, 2012 we collected tweets from the Twitter Firehose matching any of the keywords, geographical bounding boxes, and users in Table 1. During the same time period, we collected tweets from the Streaming API

query: Which centrality measure shows the smallest difference between the two data sources, and how does this relate to the convergence pattern of the dotted line?
answer: The Clustering Coefficient shows the smallest difference (0.029 vs 0.033 for avg.day), which corresponds to the dotted median line stabilizing around 0.55-0.58 after n=100, indicating that mid-range hashtag rankings converge similarly across both APIs due to comparable local network clustering patterns.

visual_anchors.anchor: dotted line labeled 'Median' stabilizing around 0.55-0.58 after n=100
Clustering Coefficient row showing 0.029 and 0.033 values

text_evidence: One of the key questions we ask in this work is how the amount of coverage affects measures commonly performed on Twitter data.

query: Which domain-pair transfer achieves the highest performance when the model successfully removes the color-coded demographic separation visible in the scatter plot?
answer: The electronics-to-kitchen transfer achieves the highest performance with VFAE at 0.850 and DANN at 0.854. query: How does the magnitude of improvement over the baseline approach in the left panel at moderate bias levels translate to actual prediction accuracy gains on the datasets?
answer: At α≈0.5, IPS and SNIPS show approximately 10x lower RMSE compared to Naive (0.01-0.02 vs ~1.0) in the MSE panel. This translates to MF-IPS achieving 30% lower MAE (0.810 vs 1.154) and 48% lower MSE (0.989 vs 1.891) than MF-Naive on Yahoo, demonstrating substantial real-world gains.

visual_anchors.anchor: red Naive line at approximately 1.0 RMSE versus blue IPS and green SNIPS lines at 0.01-0.02 RMSE in the left MSE panel at α=0.5
Yahoo MAE and MSE columns comparing first row MF-IPS values against second row MF-Naive values

text_evidence: Figure 2 reports how accurately (in terms of root mean squared estimation error (RMSE)) each estimator performs. Furthermore, the performance of MF-IPS beats the best published results for Yahoo in terms of MSE (1.115) and is close in terms of MAE (0.770)

query: What explains the performance advantage of the top-ranked method over the baseline approach that exhibits exponential degradation under propensity uncertainty?
answer: MF-IPS outperforms MF-Naive by 0.344 MAE and 0.902 MSE on YAHOO. The red line (Naive) in Figure 4 starts at 10^6 RMSE and remains orders of magnitude worse than IPS, because Naive lacks propensity correction and degrades exponentially, while IPS maintains robustness.

visual_anchors.anchor: red horizontal line labeled Naive at 10^6 RMSE level, highest among all methods
first two rows under YAHOO showing MF-IPS with 0.810 MAE versus MF-Naive with 1.154 MAE

text_evidence: Under no condition do the IPS and SNIPS estimator perform worse than Naive. Interestingly, IPS-NB with estimated propensities can perform even better than IPS-KNOWN with known propensities

query: What platform feature shown in the interface explains why later user groups consistently produce shorter contributions across all measurement periods?
answer: The voting system displayed in the interface (upvotes/downvotes affecting display order) explains the declining comment lengths. Later cohorts (2012-2014) write shorter comments (167-176 characters overall) compared to earlier cohorts (2007-2011, 182-220 characters overall), because users adapted to optimize for visibility through the voting mechanism rather than lengthy discourse.

visual_anchors.anchor: upvote/downvote arrows and comment display ordering mechanism visible in the Reddit interface
rightmost 'Overall' column showing declining values from 220 (2007) down to 176 (2014)

text_evidence: Redditors can also vote on both submissions and comments; these votes affect the order in which submissions and comments are displayed

query: What explains the strong correlation between the two embedding spaces despite the performance scores remaining nearly identical across all three evaluation conditions?
answer: The high Spearman correlation (ρ = 0.81) between w2vNEWS and GloVe embeddings shown in the scatter plot reflects consistent gender bias patterns across different embedding methods. Meanwhile, the performance metrics (RG: 76.1→76.9, WS: 70.0→69.7, analogy: 71.2 constant) demonstrate that debiasing preserves utility while addressing the stereotypical occupation-gender associations visible in the projection.

visual_anchors.anchor: scatter plot showing occupation words projected onto she-he axes with Spearman correlation of 0.81
three rows showing Before, Hard-debiased, and Soft-debiased scores across RG, WS, and analogy columns

text_evidence: the gender bias of occupations is highly consistent across embeddings (Spearman $\rho = 0 . 8 1$ ). Evalution based on the standard metrics shows that the debiasing does not degrade the utility of the embedding

query: Which debiasing approach achieves the highest coherence score while maintaining the cross-embedding consistency pattern observed in the occupation word projections?
answer: The Soft-debiased approach achieves the highest RG coherence score of 76.9, compared to 76.1 before debiasing. This improvement occurs while preserving the strong cross-embedding consistency (Spearman ρ = 0.81) demonstrated by the tight linear relationship in the occupation word projections across both w2vNEWS and GloVe embeddings.

visual_anchors.anchor: RG column showing progression from 76.1 to 76.5 to 76.9 across the three debiasing conditions
diagonal pattern of dots showing linear relationship between the two embedding axes with correlation coefficient

text_evidence: Comparing the bias of two different embeddings–the w2vNEWS and the GloVe web-crawl embedding. Evalution based on the standard metrics shows that the debiasing does not degrade the utility of the embedding

query: Which debiasing approach maintains the projection axis separation while producing the smallest change in the rightmost evaluation metric?
answer: The soft-debiased approach maintains the gender neutrality separation (y-axis) while producing the smallest change in the analogy metric (56.8 vs. 57.0). This occurs because soft-debiasing preserves more of the original embedding structure compared to hard-debiasing, which shows identical RG and WS scores (62.4, 54.1) to hard-debiasing.

visual_anchors.anchor: the y-axis direction learned in the embedding that captures gender neutrality, with gender neutral words above the line and gender specific words below
the Soft-debiased row showing 62.4, 54.2, and 56.8 across the three columns, with the analogy column (rightmost) showing minimal change from 57.0

text_evidence: for both the hard-debiased and the soft-debiased embeddings, we automatically generated pairs of words that are analogous to she-he and asked crowd-workers to evaluate whether these pairs reflect gender stereotypes

query: What quantitative performance does the dashed boundary achieve when both fairness metrics are simultaneously constrained, compared to the unconstrained solid boundary?
answer: The dashed decision boundary, which represents the fair classifier shown in panel (c), achieves an accuracy of 0.80 with FPR=0.15:0.13 and FNR=0.27:0.27 when removing disparate mistreatment with respect to both false positive and false negative rates. This contrasts with the solid boundary's accuracy of 0.85 with FPR=0.25:0.06 and FNR=0.14:0.14.

visual_anchors.anchor: panel (c) showing solid cyan line (original boundary) versus dashed purple line (fair boundary) separating red and green point clusters
second row showing accuracy 0.643 with values 0.03, -0.11 in columns 2-3, and third row showing 0.659 with 0.02, -0.08

text_evidence: Panel (c) shows the original decision boundary (solid line) and fair decision boundary (dashed line), along with corresponding accuracy

query: What explains the opposite directional adjustments of the two diagonal decision boundaries when constrained on false positive rates?
answer: The decision boundaries adjust in opposite directions because the recidivism base rates differ substantially between races: the group represented by circles has 52% recidivism while the group shown as crosses has only 39% recidivism. This 13-percentage-point gap in base rates (52% vs 39%) causes the FPR constraint to push the boundaries in opposite directions to equalize false positive rates across the two populations.

visual_anchors.anchor: two diagonal lines (solid cyan and dotted blue) with opposite slopes, one moving upward-left and one moving downward-right, separating red circles from green crosses
first data column showing Yes percentages: 52% in first row versus 39% in second row

text_evidence: Removing disparate mistreatment on only false positive rate causes a

query: Why does the dotted boundary achieve lower disparate mistreatment on one metric while the racial group with higher recidivism rate shows a specific percentage split?
answer: The dotted boundary (Acc=0.69) achieves FPR=0.57:0.58 and FNR=0.08:0.01, showing lower FPR disparity. This matches the Black group's 52% vs 48% split (1,661 vs 1,514), where the higher recidivism rate (52%) requires balancing false positives to avoid exacerbating disparate mistreatment on FNR.

visual_anchors.anchor: dotted blue decision boundary with Acc=0.69; FPR=0.57:0.58; FNR=0.08:0.01 metrics
Black row showing 1,661(52%) in Yes column and 1,514(48%) in No column

text_evidence: controlling disparate mistreatment for only false positive rate (false negative rate), leads to a minor drop in accuracy, but can exacerbate the disparate mistreatment on false negative rate (false positive rate)

query: What accuracy penalty occurs when enforcing both constraints simultaneously, and how does this relate to the imbalance direction between the two racial groups?
answer: Enforcing both constraints drops accuracy from 0.80 to 0.69 (11 percentage points). This larger penalty occurs because Black defendants show 52% recidivism (Yes) while White defendants show 61% non-recidivism (No), requiring the classifier to balance opposing disparate mistreatment directions simultaneously.

visual_anchors.anchor: solid cyan line (Acc=0.80) versus dotted blue line (Acc=0.69) showing accuracy drop
Black row 52% Yes versus White row 61% No, showing opposite majority outcomes

text_evidence: Removing disparate mistreatment on both at the same time causes a larger drop in accuracy

query: What causal relationship enables the partitioning criterion, and how are the positive decision counts distributed across demographic groups in each partition?
answer: The conditional independence (C ⊥ E | B) in the modified causal graph enables meaningful partitioning because block sets satisfy this criterion. Within each subpopulation q, positive decisions are distributed as n^(c+e+)_q for the protected group and n^(c+e+)_q for the non-protected group, with totals n^(e+)_q across both groups.

visual_anchors.anchor: The directed edges from gender to major and from gender to admission, with major also pointing to admission
The positive decision column showing n^(c+e+)_q for protected group row, n^(c+e+)_q for non-protected group row, and n^(e+)_q total

text_evidence: A node set B forms a meaningful partition for measuring discrimination if and only if B is a block set, i.e., B satisfies: (1) (C ⊥ E | B) holds

query: Which attributes in the causal network form the block sets that determine how to partition the contingency counts when measuring direct discrimination?
answer: The green nodes (age and edu) and their combinations form block sets that partition the data. Within each subpopulation q, the contingency table shows counts like n^(c+e+)_q and n^(c-e-)_q that are used to calculate ΔP|_q, the direct discriminatory effect after blocking confounding paths.

visual_anchors.anchor: green nodes labeled age and edu with multiple incoming and outgoing edges
notation n^(c+e+)_q, n^(c-e-)_q in cells showing protected/non-protected group counts

text_evidence: There are two block sets in this graph: {major}, and {major,test score}. Note that test score alone is not a block set.

query: What role does the protected attribute play in structuring the rows of the subpopulation-specific counts used to compute the direct discriminatory effect?
answer: The red node (sex) serves as the protected attribute c, which defines the two rows in the contingency table: protected group (c-) and non-protected group (c+). The counts n^(c+e+)_q and n^(c-e+)_q are then used to calculate ΔP|_q = n^(c+e+)_q/n^(c+)_q - n^(c-e+)_q/n^(c-)_q within each subpopulation.

visual_anchors.anchor: red node labeled sex at top right with edges to multiple variables
first column showing protected group (c-) and non-protected group (c+) rows

text_evidence: To calculate the number of tuples to be modified within each subpopulation q, we express ΔP|_q as n^(c+e+)_q/n^(c+)_q - n^(c-e+)_q/n^(c-)_q

query: Which demographic attribute highlighted in the causal structure has identical overall admission percentages across both protected groups in the second example?
answer: The sex attribute (shown as the red node in the causal graph) has identical overall admission rates of 43% for both females and males in Example 2, despite different admission patterns across majors.

visual_anchors.anchor: red node labeled 'sex' representing the protected attribute
bottom row showing 38%, 38%, 47%, 47% percentages across gender-major combinations

text_evidence: Consider a different example on the same toy model shown in Table 2. The average admission rate now becomes $43 \%$ equally for both females and males.

query: Which intermediate variable highlighted in the network structure corresponds to the strongest indirect discrimination measure after applying the removal method?
answer: The marital_status node, shown in blue paths in the causal network, corresponds to the strongest indirect discrimination. After applying the discrimination removal method, LMSG achieves an indirect value of 0.288 in training and 0.271 in prediction (SVM and DTree), which are the highest indirect discrimination values marked in bold.

visual_anchors.anchor: blue paths passing through the marital_status node in the center of the network
LMSG column showing indirect values 0.288 (Train) and 0.271 (Predict rows) in bold

text_evidence: the green path represents the direct path, and the blue paths represent the indirect paths passing through marital status

query: Which fairness approach that removes race and sex from the causal pathway achieves the lowest prediction error among the constrained models?
answer: The Fair Add approach achieves an RMSE of 0.918, which is lower than Fair K's 0.929. This corresponds to the additive error model shown in Level 3 of the causal diagram, where GPA, LSAT, and FYA have independent error terms that may be correlated with one another.

visual_anchors.anchor: Level 3 causal graph showing additive error structure with epsilon terms for GPA, LSAT, and FYA
RMSE row showing Fair K value 0.929 and Fair Add value 0.918

text_evidence: In Level 3, we model GPA, LSAT, and FYA as continuous variables with additive error terms independent of race and sex (that may in turn be correlated with one-another).

query: What accuracy cost in prediction error results from enforcing counterfactual fairness compared to the model using all demographic features and test scores?
answer: The Full model achieves an RMSE of 0.873, while the Fair K model has 0.929, representing a degradation of 0.056. The density plots show that Fair K produces predicted FYA distributions (teal and red curves) that are more overlapped across demographic groups compared to the Full model's separated distributions.

visual_anchors.anchor: Density plots showing teal and red curves for predicted FYA across black-white, asian-white, mexican-white, and female-male comparisons
RMSE row comparing Full model value 0.873 with Fair K value 0.929

text_evidence: Note that we must sacrifice a small amount of accuracy to ensuring counterfactually fair prediction (Fair K, Fair Add), versus the models that use unfair features: GPA, LSAT, race, sex (Full, Unaware).

query: Which modeling approach with intermediate employment nodes achieves the smallest performance penalty when enforcing fairness constraints compared to the unrestricted baseline?
answer: The Fair K approach achieves an RMSE of 0.929, representing a performance penalty of 0.056 compared to the Full model's 0.873. This corresponds to the causal model in subfigure (e) that expands to include intermediate employment variables, demonstrating that modeling the causal pathway through employment allows for fairer predictions with moderate accuracy trade-offs.

visual_anchors.anchor: subfigure (e) showing the expanded causal graph with intermediate Employed nodes connecting attributes A to outcomes Y
RMSE row comparing Full (0.873), Fair K (0.929), and Fair Add (0.918) values

text_evidence: Expanding the model to include an intermediate variable indicating whether the individual is employ

query: Which recognition task type corresponds to the semantic role labeling examples, and how does its vocabulary size compare to the alternative approach?
answer: The semantic role labeling examples showing cooking activities with agent, food, heat, tool, and place roles correspond to the vSRL (visual Semantic Role Labeling) task in imSitu. This task has 212 verbs, which is more than three times larger than the MLC (Multi-Label Classification) task in MS-COCO that has 66 objects.

visual_anchors.anchor: Five images with structured role-value tables showing ROLE column (AGENT, FOOD, HEAT, TOOL, PLACE) and VALUE column with specific nouns
Column showing O-Type as 'verb' with ||O||=212 versus 'object' with ||O||=66

text_evidence: In vSRL, we consider gender bias relating to verbs, while in MLC we consider the gender bias related to objects... the cooking activity in imSitu is a heavily biased verb

query: Which dataset with the highest baseline accuracy shows the most dramatic visual separation between protected groups in the probability scatter, and what fairness improvement was achieved?
answer: The Marketing dataset achieves 0.89 accuracy with naive classification and shows a dramatic horizontal separation in the scatter plot between female (blue) and male (yellow) probability distributions. The fair constrained classification achieves a 102% p-% rule, indicating near-perfect demographic parity, because the DLP method successfully eliminates the treatment disparity visible in the scatter.

visual_anchors.anchor: horizontal separation between blue (female) and yellow (male) probability distributions along the x-axis showing p(female) values
Marketing row showing 0.89 accuracy in column f and 102% in column k

text_evidence: Note that the $p \%$ rules from [5] were the strongest that could be obtained with their method; on complex datasets $p \%$ rules of $100 \%$ are rarely obtained in practice

query: For the dataset where downward and upward triangles indicate altered admission decisions, what proportion of applicants belong to the protected class and how does the constrained method compare to naive classification?
answer: The graduate admissions visualization shows triangles representing treatment-altered decisions, corresponding to the Employee dataset where 45.8% are protected (column b). The fair constrained classification achieves 8%/11% prot./non-prot. in positive (column j) with 69% p-%, while naive classification shows 8%/12% with 65% p-%, demonstrating modest fairness improvement due to the DLP's selective decision alterations visible as triangles.

visual_anchors.anchor: downward triangles indicating rejected individuals and upward triangles indicating accepted individuals after DLP treatment
Employee row showing 45.8% in column b, 8%/12% in column g, and 8%/11% in column j

text_evidence: Downward triangles indicate individuals rejected only after applying the DLP ("treatment"), while upward triangles indicate individuals accepted only by the DLP

query: What conditioning factor causes the session-based activity metric to exhibit paradoxical behavior when controlling for user credibility measures?
answer: Reputation serves as the conditioning variable for Session length. When Session length acts as the independent variable and data is disaggregated on Reputation, the trend in answer acceptance reverses, demonstrating Simpson's paradox. This explains why the aggregate trend in the scatter plot does not hold within reputation-stratified subgroups.

visual_anchors.anchor: the dense cluster of data points between 10,000 and 30,000 answers showing acceptance probability around 0.6-0.7
the second row showing Session length as independent variable paired with Reputation as conditioning variable

text_evidence: Our approach automatically identies this example as Simpson's paradox, as illustrated in Fig. 1. e gure shows average ac

query: Which conditioning strategy reverses the downward trend observed in the aggregated data when users reach approximately one thousand contributions?
answer: When conditioning on Reputation, the trend reverses for the variable 'Answer position' (as listed in the third row of the systematic paradox table). The downward aggregated trend visible around 1000 answers becomes upward when disaggregated by reputation, because more experienced users with higher reputation tend to answer later in the queue during longer sessions.

visual_anchors.anchor: multiple colored trend lines showing declining acceptance probability as number of answers increases from 0 to 2000, with most lines converging around 1000-1200 answers
third row showing Answer position as independent variable with Reputation as conditioning variable

text_evidence: Our approach automatically identies this example as Simpson's paradox, as illustrated in Fig. 1. e gure shows average ac

query: What temporal factor creates the paradox when examining how the timing gap between consecutive contributions affects acceptance rates?
answer: The temporal factor is 'Answer position' serving as the conditioning variable (shown in the sixth row). When the time gap between consecutive answers is disaggregated by answer position, the paradox emerges because answers written with longer time gaps tend to occur at different positions in the answer queue, reversing the aggregate trend visible in the declining curves.

visual_anchors.anchor: downward-sloping dashed and solid lines in various colors (red, blue, purple, orange) showing acceptance probability declining from 0.5 to 0.2-0.4 range
sixth row listing Time since previous answer as independent variable with Answer position as conditioning variable

text_evidence: e eleven variables in Stack Exchange data, result in 110 possible Simpson's pairs. Among these, our method identies seven as instance of paradox. ese are listed in Table 1.

query: Which session length category contributes most heavily to the paradox, and how does its trajectory compare to the most experienced user group?
answer: The single-answer session length (1.2M data points) contributes most heavily to the paradox. Its green trajectory shows acceptance probability declining from approximately 0.55 to 0.28, while the most experienced users (gray triangles) decline from about 0.55 to 0.35, demonstrating that the shortest sessions have steeper decline rates despite their dominance in the dataset.

visual_anchors.anchor: the green dashed line with circular markers showing steep decline and the gray triangular markers showing more gradual decline
the first row entry with the largest value of 1.2M compared to all other session length counts

text_evidence: Table 2 reports the number of sessions of different length. By far, the most common session has length one: users write only one answer during these sessions

query: Which input pathways feed into the adversary component shown in the proof diagram, and what data types characterize those pathways?
answer: The adversary receives $\hat{Y}$ (predicted income) and can also receive $Y$ (true income label) for equality of odds. The income feature is categorical (Cat), representing whether an individual makes > $50K annually, while the prediction $\hat{Y}$ flows from the model's output layer as shown in the diagram.

visual_anchors.anchor: arrows pointing into the adversary box from prediction and label sources
income row showing Cat type and the $50K threshold description

text_evidence: for equality of odds, it can be given both $\hat { Y }$ and $Y$. We use embeddings trained for the task of predicting the income of a person – in particular, predicting whether the income is $> { \mathfrak { S } } 5 0 k$

query: Which types of input attributes feed into the first component that produces intermediate predictions before the debiasing stage?
answer: The Predictor Weights component receives both continuous features (age, capital_gain, capital_loss, education_num, fnlwgt, hours_per_week) and categorical features (education, income, marital_status, native_country, occupation, race, relationship, sex, workclass) as inputs. These 15 total features are processed to generate ŷ predictions because the architecture shows the predictor as the first stage receiving x inputs.

visual_anchors.anchor: the leftmost box labeled 'Predictor Weights: W' receiving input x and outputting ŷ
all rows showing Feature names with Type column indicating Cont or Cat

text_evidence: predicting whether the income is $> { \mathfrak { S } } 5 0 k$ – given various attributes about the person, as made available in

query: What demographic attribute with only two possible values is the second-stage component designed to prevent from being predictable?
answer: The Adversary Weights component is designed to prevent sex (Female, Male) from being predictable. This is because the adversarial network architecture aims to debias predictions by making the protected attribute unpredictable from ŷ, and sex is a binary categorical feature that commonly requires debiasing in fairness applications.

visual_anchors.anchor: the rightmost box labeled 'Adversary Weights: U' receiving ŷ and outputting ẑ with loss function L_A
the row labeled 'sex' with Type 'Cat' and Description showing two gender categories

text_evidence: Bolukbasi et al. (2016) devises a method to remove gender bias from word embeddings

query: Which causal pathway involving the protected attribute shows the most dramatic reduction in distributional discrepancy as training progresses beyond the initial checkpoint?
answer: The pathway through marital status (M) shows the most dramatic MMD reduction, dropping from 610.85 (×10,000) at 5,000 steps to 2.97 at 15,000 steps in the Adult dataset. This corresponds to the direct edge from the protected node A to the middle-layer node M in the graphical structure, where marital status mediates the effect on income prediction Y.

query: What structural difference between the two datasets explains why one maintains consistently lower distributional discrepancy values across all latent representations throughout training?
answer: The German Credit dataset (right graph) has a simpler causal structure with fewer mediating paths from A to Y, maintaining lower MMD values (all under 7.0 ×10,000) compared to the Adult dataset. The Adult dataset's complex multi-path structure through nodes like M, S, and R creates higher initial discrepancy (610.85) that requires more training steps to resolve.

query: How do the distributional similarity metrics evolve across training iterations when enforcing fairness constraints on the causal structure with confounding?
answer: The MMD values for the three hidden representations show distinct evolution patterns: Hm decreases from 13.31 to 6.31 (×10,000), while Hl and Hr remain consistently low (below 0.25 and 0.50 respectively) across all training steps from 5,000 to 20,000. This pattern corresponds to the causal structure where confounder C affects both M and Y, requiring stronger distributional alignment for the M-related representation.

query: Which evaluation approach shows the strongest alignment with the gender-based linguistic patterns when the pronoun refers to the occupation itself rather than the other participant?
answer: The rule-based approach (RULE) shows the strongest alignment with a correlation of 0.87 when the pronoun is coreferent with OCCUPATION (B&L condition). This high correlation occurs because the rule-based system most closely follows the gender stereotypes embedded in the occupation-pronoun templates where PRONOUN is coreferent with OCCUPATION, as shown in sentence (1a) and (1b).

visual_anchors.anchor: sentence templates (1a) and (1b) where 'The paramedic' is highlighted in green and the pronoun 'she/he/they' refers back to the occupation
first row (B&L) showing correlation values 0.87, 0.46, and 0.35 across three columns

text_evidence: For each occupation, we wrote two similar sentence templates: one in which PRONOUN is coreferent with OCCUPATION, and one in which it is coreferent with PARTICIPANT

query: Which system shows the steepest upward trend line and what performance gap emerges when stereotypes are challenged versus reinforced?
answer: The RULE system shows the steepest upward trend (green line with triangular markers). When stereotypes are challenged ("gotcha" cases), RULE accuracy drops from 38.3% to 10.0% for female pronouns and from 51.7% to 37.5% for male pronouns, demonstrating severe performance degradation when real-world gender biases cannot be exploited.

visual_anchors.anchor: green line with triangular markers showing steep positive slope from bottom-left to top-right
RULE system rows showing accuracy values split between 'no' and 'yes' gotcha conditions

text_evidence: When these systems' predictions diverge based on pronoun gender, they do so in ways that reinforce and magnify real-world occupational gender disparities.

query: What training approach dominates among respondents, and which module characteristic in the prototype requires the most human involvement to generate?
answer: The majority (58.6%, 34 respondents) learned data analysis through self-directed methods. This aligns with the Manual Effort characteristic in the prototype modules, where some modules require significant human input while others are fully automated, as shown in Table 2.

visual_anchors.anchor: largest blue segment occupying more than half the donut chart in panel B
Manual Effort row showing variability across modules

text_evidence: While the generation of some modules is fully automated, some require human input (Table 2​).

query: Which learning method represents the smallest institutional contribution, and what module property in the framework reflects the need for expert judgment versus automation?
answer: Employer Training represents only 3.4% (2 respondents), the smallest institutional contribution. This minimal formal training context corresponds to the Subjectivity characteristic in Table 2, which captures whether modules rely on expert judgment or objective automated processes.

visual_anchors.anchor: smallest green segment at the top of the donut chart showing minimal percentage
Subjectivity row indicating variation in human judgment requirements

text_evidence: The resulting prototype successfully demonstrates how disparate modules can be built on a specific dataset in order to highlight multiple, complementary facets of the data

query: Given that the majority of respondents learned through self-directed methods, which module addresses the fundamental information needed before any analysis begins?
answer: The Metadata module is the only required module and represents the absolute minimum information to be presented. It contains filename, file format, URL, domain, keywords, type, dataset size, percentage of missing cells, license, release date, collection range, and description. This foundational module supports the 58.6% (34 respondents) who learned data analysis through self-directed means by providing essential dataset context.

visual_anchors.anchor: The largest blue segment occupying more than half the donut chart, labeled with the highest percentage and count
The first data row describing the only required module with its comprehensive contents list

text_evidence: Meta information. This module is the only required module. It represents the absolute minimum information to be presented

query: How does the distribution pattern of attribute dots relative to the fairness baseline explain the progression of discrimination metrics across the generative model variants?
answer: The scatter plot shows SYN4-FairGAN's dots tightly clustered along the diagonal fairness line, while earlier variants deviate more. This visual pattern matches the risk difference progression in Table 1: SYN1-GAN maintains high discrimination (0.1943), while SYN4-FairGAN achieves the lowest (0.0411), because FairGAN explicitly minimizes conditional probability disparities between protected groups.

visual_anchors.anchor: vertical and horizontal deviation of individual attribute dots from the red diagonal line indicating probability distribution imbalance
sequential columns from left to right showing risk difference values for SYN1 through SYN4

query: Which synthetic approach trained with dual discriminators achieves the lowest risk difference, and how does its architecture differ from the single-discriminator baseline?
answer: SYN4-FairGAN achieves the lowest risk difference at 0.0037±0.0003. Its architecture includes two discriminators (D₁ and D₂) that separately evaluate real versus fake data and the sensitive attribute ŝ, whereas the single-discriminator baseline (SYN1-GAN with 0.1798±0.0026) uses only D₁ for distinguishing real from generated samples.

visual_anchors.anchor: Two discriminator components D₁ and D₂ shown in rounded rectangles, with D₂ receiving input (x̂, ŷ|ŝ = 0) and (x̂, ŷ|ŝ = 1)
Rightmost column showing SYN4-FairGAN with value 0.0037±0.0003 compared to SYN1-GAN at 0.1798±0.0026

text_evidence: The SYN-GAN, which is trained to be close to the real dataset, has the similar risk difference to the real dataset. On the contrary, SYN2-

query: Which embedding approach shows the tightest clustering around the neutral axis, and what percentage of predictions does it achieve for the primary task category?
answer: GN-GloVe shows the tightest clustering around the neutral axis (similarity ≈ 0) in the visualization. This model achieves 97.7% Definition predictions on the full SemBias dataset, substantially higher than GloVe (80.2%) and Hard-GloVe (84.1%), demonstrating that reduced gender bias leads to better performance on gender-definition analogies.

visual_anchors.anchor: the narrowest vertical scatter pattern centered near zero similarity, with minimal horizontal spread
the Definition column in the SemBias dataset section, third row

text_evidence: the gender information has been substantially diminished from $w ^ { ( a ) }$ in the GN-GloVe embedding.

query: For the embedding model displaying the widest horizontal spread of occupation terms, what is the ratio between its stereotype and none-category predictions on the restricted evaluation?
answer: The GloVe model displays the widest horizontal spread in the visualization, with terms ranging from approximately -0.5 to +0.5 similarity. On the SemBias (subset), GloVe achieves 20% Stereotype and 22.5% None predictions, yielding a ratio of approximately 0.89, indicating relatively balanced but still present gender bias in the restricted evaluation.

visual_anchors.anchor: the scatter plot with the largest range along the horizontal similarity axis, extending furthest from the vertical center
the Stereotype and None columns in the SemBias (subset) section, first row

text_evidence: To test the generalization ability of the model, we generate a subset of data (SemBias (subset)) of 40 instances associated with these 2 pairs.

query: Which occupation category concentrates in the region where the distribution peaks, and what sentence structure is used to test this category in the gender-neutral source?
answer: STEM fields concentrate mainly at X ≥ 6, which aligns with the peak at X = 6 in the male pronoun distribution. For example, the Hungarian template "ő egy ⟨occupation⟩" is used to test STEM occupations, where the gender-neutral pronoun "ő" is translated to reveal bias.

visual_anchors.anchor: the peak at X = 6 and the rightward concentration of the yellow STEM category bars
the Hungarian row showing the occupation sentence template with the pronoun placeholder

text_evidence: STEM fields concentrate mainly to the right ( $X \geq 6$ ). Specifically, we can translate sentences such as the Hungarian "˝o egy ´apol´

query: Which learning method achieves the highest population outcome under the constrained policy, and how does its incarceration pattern differ from the unconstrained approach at mid-range parameter values?
answer: Q-learning achieves the highest population outcome under Fair Policy at 1.189±0.0059. At utility parameter values between 2 and 3, the dashed line (optimal fair policy) shows a sharp drop to near-zero incarceration before rising steeply, while the solid line (optimal unfair policy) maintains a steady moderate incarceration rate around 0.2-0.3.

visual_anchors.anchor: dashed line showing sharp drop to near-zero between utility parameter 2 and 3, then steep rise
Q-learning row, Fair Policy column showing 1.189±0.0059

text_evidence: The region of particular interest is between $\theta = 2$ and 3, where fair and unrestricted optimal policies differ

query: What explains the performance gap between the two estimation approaches in the rightmost column, and where does this difference manifest visually in the incarceration trajectories?
answer: G-estimation achieves 1.312±0.0102 under Fair Policy, outperforming value search's 1.056±0.0299 by approximately 0.25. This difference manifests in the upper-right region where the dashed line reaches incarceration rates above 0.6, indicating g-estimation better captures the high-utility regime where aggressive fair policies maximize outcomes.

visual_anchors.anchor: g-estimation and value search rows under Fair Policy column, showing 1.312 versus 1.056
dashed line reaching above 0.6 incarceration rate at utility parameter values above 3.5

text_evidence: For low values of $\theta$ the incarceration rate is zero, and becomes higher as $\theta$ increases, but differential

query: What mathematical form corresponds to the boundary constraint that separates the classifier achieving fairness from the one making fair predictions?
answer: The boundary constraint separating the two classifiers is the κ-δ-risk difference constraint. The hinge surrogate function listed in the first row defines κ(α) = max{α,0} and δ(α) = min{α,0}, with ψκ(μ) or ψδ(μ) = μ, which directly implements the fairness constraint -c₂ ≤ RD(f) ≤ c₁ shown in the problem formulation.

visual_anchors.anchor: The horizontal dotted lines at approximately +1.5, +0.5, and -0.5 separating male (yellow) and female (blue) predictions across the two classifier scenarios
The first data row labeled 'Hinge' with κ(α) = max{α,0} and δ(α) = min{α,0} in columns 2 and 3

query: What performance gap exists between the best unsupervised approach and the strongest supervised baseline for subject identification, and which visualization panel confirms the superior identity preservation?
answer: The unsupervised method ('Ours') achieves Ay = 0.983 compared to CAI's 0.961, showing a significant boost in predicting subject identity from e1. Panel (d) confirms this superior identity preservation by showing clear clustering of e1 embeddings labeled by subject-ID with distinct numerical markers, demonstrating better separation than competing methods.

panel (d) displaying t-SNE clusters with numerical markers representing different subjects

query: What mathematical relationship between path coefficients ensures that removing one node produces equivalent causal dependencies to the original discrimination prevention scenario?
answer: The structural equation parameters theta, lambda, and beta must satisfy specific cancellation conditions where the direct effect exactly counterbalances the indirect pathway. The causal dependences being equivalent between the resolving variable case and the proxy discrimination case means the same linear coefficient relationships apply, ensuring path-specific fairness through parameter constraints.

visual_anchors.anchor: template graph structure with nodes N_P, A, N_X, P, X, and R
linear structural equation coefficients theta, lambda, beta

text_evidence: The causal dependences are equivalent to the ones in Figure 3 and we again assume linear structural equations

query: What structural parameters determine whether departmental selection acts as a fair mediator versus an unfair pathway in admission decisions?
answer: The parameters alpha, beta, and gamma govern the strength of edges from the protected attribute to the mediator and outcome nodes, determining whether the indirect path through department choice represents legitimate preferences or discriminatory influence. When the path through the mediator is considered fair, only the direct edge parameter captures unfairness, as shown in the college admission scenario.

visual_anchors.anchor: black edge from mediator node to outcome node
parameters alpha, beta, and gamma controlling edge strengths

query: Why does intervening on the proxy node eliminate certain pathways while preserving others in the discrimination avoidance framework?
answer: The intervention on P (shown in the right graph) removes incoming dashed arrows to the proxy while maintaining solid arrows to downstream nodes R and X. This surgical modification blocks specific causal pathways encoded by parameters like alpha and beta, while preserving legitimate influences through theta and lambda, thereby preventing proxy discrimination without eliminating all causal dependencies.

visual_anchors.anchor: right graph showing intervention with removed dashed arrow to P but preserved solid arrows
parameters alpha, beta, theta, and lambda representing different causal pathways

text_evidence: Right: The graph corresponding to an intervention on $P$ . The circle labeled "DAG" represents any sub-DAG of $\tilde { \mathcal { G } }$ and $\mathcal { G }$ containing an arbitrary number of variables that is compatible with the shown arrows.

query: What theoretical property governs the steeper descent in reconstruction loss observed for both demographic groups at low dimensionality?
answer: The rank-constrained optimization framework captures the largest variance directions first, leading to rapid error reduction in initial dimensions. Both gender groups exhibit steep error decline from 1 to 5 features because the minimization objective prioritizes maximal variance capture in the earliest principal components, as evidenced by the sharp downward slope in the left portion of both curves.

visual_anchors.anchor: steep downward slope of both curves between 1 and 5 features
rank constraint parameter in the optimization

text_evidence: analyzing when dimensionality reduction might inadvertently introduce bias. We focus on principal component

query: Why does the fairness-aware method maintain nearly equal reconstruction errors between demographic groups while the standard approach shows diverging trends?
answer: The fairness-aware method incorporates a max operator over population-specific reconstruction errors in its optimization objective, forcing equal magnitude constraints across groups. Figure 3 demonstrates this by showing Female loss PCA and Male loss PCA converging to similar values (around 0.5-0.6), while Fair loss remains lower and stable (around 0.2), because the optimization balances worst-case group performance rather than average performance.

visual_anchors.anchor: Female loss PCA and Male loss PCA curves converging at similar heights around 0.5-0.6
max operator over population indices in the objective function

text_evidence: women have equal magnitude in the objective function of PCA (Figure 1 right).

query: What theoretical mechanism explains why one dimensionality reduction approach achieves approximately three times lower reconstruction error than demographic-specific losses?
answer: The Fair loss curve maintains values around 0.2 while Male/Female losses reach 0.5-0.6 because the optimization minimizes a different objective. Instead of minimizing average reconstruction error, the fairness-constrained formulation uses a min-max structure that bounds the maximum reconstruction error across populations, leading to lower overall loss but balanced group-wise performance.

visual_anchors.anchor: Fair loss curve staying around 0.2 while Male/Female loss curves reach 0.5-0.6
min operator in the outer objective with max operator over groups

text_evidence: Figure 3 shows the average reconstruction error of each population (Male/Female, Higher/Lower education) as the result of running vanilla PCA and Fair PCA

query: What scale of labeled training instances supports the structured prediction approach using correlation modeling between labels and visual features?
answer: The vSRL task uses 60,000 images with 212 verb categories, while MLC uses 25,000 images with 66 object categories. These large quantities of labeled data, predominantly retrieved from the web, support the structured prediction and deep learning methods that model correlations between labels and images using the lambda and theta parameters in the optimization framework.

visual_anchors.anchor: lambda and theta parameters
Images column showing 60,000 and 25,000

text_evidence: Methods often combine structured prediction and deep learning to model correlations between labels and images to make judgments that otherwise would have weak visual support.
